Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for the 2019 ACM Sigmetrics International Conference on Measurement and Modeling of Computer Systems (Sigmetrics 2019)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ACM Sigmetrics 2019 conference will be held at the Phoenix Convention Center in Phoenix, Arizona from June 24-28, 2019, and will be part of the ACM Federated Computing Research Conference (FCRC) 2019. Sigmetrics is the premier forum for discussing the development and application of state-of-the-art, broadly applicable analytic, simulation, and measurement-based performance evaluation techniques. Historically, Sigmetrics brings together 200 or more professionals from academic and industrial backgrounds. The technical program of Sigmetrics includes research and work-in-progress poster presentations of refereed papers, workshops, tutorials, panel discussions, and invited keynote talks by the world's leading experts in the area of performance evaluation of computer systems. Sigmetrics provides an international forum for presentation of original research results as well as exchange and dissemination of innovative and practical systems modeling ideas, which are particularly valuable for student participants.

This grant provides travel support for about 25 U.S. based graduate student participants to attend the Sigmetrics 2019 conference. A strong representation of U.S. researchers at the conference, particularly students, is essential in maintaining U.S. competitiveness. This grant will provide travel support for students based on merit and need, and particular emphasis will be placed on diversity for the selection of awardees to increase participation of under-represented groups. This support will help students attend the conference and interact with professionals in both industry and academia. Taking part in the educational experiences available at Sigmetrics, including tutorial sessions and workshops, will provide students with important learning and mentoring opportunities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to offer travel grants to help students attend the ACM Sigmetrics 2019 conference, which is the premiere conference on performance modeling and measurement of computer systems and networks. The conference was held at the Phoenix Convention Center in Phoenix, Arizona from June 24–28, 2019; the PI served as the Student Activities Chair for the conference. Sigmetrics 2019 was part of the ACM Federated Computing Research Conference (FCRC) 2019, and was thus colocated with other leading conferences in other communities including ISCA 2019, STOC 2019, COLT 2019, SPAA 2019, and PLDI 2019. 

The funds for this project supported the travel and accommodation of 27 graduate students. Most grant recipients were presenting a paper or poster at ACM Sigmetrics or an associated workshop. 15 of these were first time Sigmetrics attendees.

A key intellectual merit of the project consisted of the ideas the funded students brought to the conference through their presentations and the various discussions they had with leading experts in the field who regularly attend Sigmetrics. The PI also organized and moderated a Student Panel which consisted of panelists from Academia who answered student questions over a 2-hour panel (colocated with Sigmetrics).

The broader impact of the grant consisted of exposing these young and budding researchers to top-notch research in performance evaluation. In terms of promoting diversity, the funded students represented 16 different universities from different parts of the US. Among them, three were female students and two were from other underrepresented communities.
